[h1] An instant classic [/h1]
Celeste blends the best controlling character I've ever played in a platformer, with a banging soundtrack and uncompromising challenge to cook up an earnest masterpiece. Yes, [u] masterpiece [/u].

The game is difficult, often crushingly so. But in Celeste, Death is a point of pride. Painless, quick and easy. Each [strike] death [/strike] attempt brings you back to try again in split seconds. Music continues through each screen so there's little in the way of interruption.

Story is charming, interwoven with gameplay to create some truly memorable set-piece moments and encounters. My favourite being [spoiler] just play the game for yourself [/spoiler]

Madeline just feels [i] good to control [/i]. From expressive pixel animations, fluid movement and full air-mobility. Under the hood, there are little additions that further enhance the game, such as coyote time and generous hitboxes.

151230252.review:
[h1]  Celeste [/h1]

Out of the many years I've dedicated to this medium, Celeste is at the very pinnacle of what I would consider some of the finest, most passionate, personal, and fun video games that I have ever played. Celeste is my first and proper exposure to a platformer, and I couldn't have picked a better game to be my teacher. Playing through Celeste felt like an intense emotional journey, and by the time the credits start rolling, I feel like I've never been more intertwined, both personally and emotionally, with a character's purpose and motivation than I was with Madeline's journey to conqueror Mount Celeste. To understand what makes Celeste feel so unique and fresh to play, I need to go over what I believe to be its best strengths while addressing some of its more questionable and eye-raising design and creative decisions. 

[h2] What I Loved About Celeste ▼ [/h2]

[b] 1. The Story [/b]
An odd thing to praise considering most platformers are not known for their stories, but Celeste is unlike most. A few people have said that Celeste is a fantastic example of a video game serving as a catalyst for positive change, and as ridiculous as that sounds at first, I think they might be right. Regardless of where one is in life, Celeste deals with themes and topics we can all relate to and understand: Self-loathing, self-forgiveness, the courage to face your problems, and finding inner strength to grow. And Maddy, the writer of Celeste, executed her themes perfectly without it ever sounding cliche, sappy, or preachy. As a result, the journey of Madeline becomes the journey of the player, and at the risk of sounding overly sentimental, I feel like I grew too. Becoming kinder, not only to myself but also to other people. It's a story I'm sure many players could identify with, and I hope they come to appreciate it as much as I do. 

[b] 2. The Sadistic Gameplay [/b]
It's not an exaggeration when I say that Celeste is perhaps the most difficult game I have ever played. But damn, is it f#cking good! The gameplay is tighter than a [spoiler] my lawyer has advised me not to finish this joke [/spoiler]. The level designs are as creative as it is challenging, always pushing players past their comfort zones and never being afraid to demand technical proficiency from their audience. Every chapter introduces something new to spice up the gameplay, and it's rewarding to beat like any skill-based game should. It's addicting, and I couldn't get enough of it. It's Precision Puzzle Platformer done right.

[b] 3. The Phenomenal Soundtrack [/b]
Composed by Lena Raine, the OST is nothing short of a certified banger. Every track captures the mood and feeling of the game perfectly and is the secret sauce behind the success of Celeste. It's the cherry on top of atomic proportion and serves as the player's comforting orchestra of failure as you accidentally dash yourself into yet another wall of spikes for the hundredth times, and wonder why god hates you. But hey, at least the beautiful music soothes the pain. Jokes aside, definitely a strong contender for one of my favorite soundtracks of all time. 

[b] 4. The Art [/b]
What else can I say that you can't already see for yourself? The game's freaking gorgeous. It's colorful, cute, and oozes personality thanks to its strong visual style and presentation. The artists did a terrific job with Celeste. Enough said. 

[b] 5. The Strawberries [/b]
Celeste is one of the few games that manages to implement hard mode in one of the cleverest ways I've ever seen. Whereas most games asked you to choose a difficulty option before starting, Celeste took another route and embedded its hard mode directly into the gameplay using strawberry collectibles. They act almost like bait, luring and enticing players to come and get them, but with a catch: They are always situated in the most dicey and difficult-to-reach spot on the stage. And since these strawberries are entirely optional to collect, they act as a brilliant way to subtly and subconsciously encourage players to be adventurous with their risk-taking without ever forcing anything on them.  

[h2] What I Not So Loved About Celeste ▼ [/h2]

[b] 1. The Epilogues [/b]
Chapters eight and nine serve as the epilogues, and in my opinion, they are entirely unnecessary and pointless additions to what was otherwise an already perfect ending. Chapter seven acts as a meaningful ending and emotional climax for Madeline's character arc and finishes her story on a high with hopeful optimism that leaves players completely satisfied and content. Why bring her back only to introduce so little in the way of narrative significance? The ending left players on an emotional high point and should've stayed that way. Chapters eight and nine needlessly extended the run time for what is little more than side stories.
Think about the endings to all your favorite games and movies. Now imagine what would happen if they were all extended by another 2 hours. Yeah, exactly. Emotional pacing ruined. 

[b] 2. The Insane Difficulty [/b]
Specifically, chapters eight and nine including B-sides and C-sides. Before anybody starts losing respect for me due to this criticism, let me explain. I've never been one to complain about a game being too punishing. Truthfully, not even once. So, believe me when I say the difficulties of Celeste's epilogues and side content border on the insane and the unreasonable. To put it into perspective, has anyone seen those crazy viral Super Mario Maker levels where it's so tough that only a handful of people have managed to beat it? Yeah, Celeste is not only kissing that, but also giving it a run for its money. When something is that unbalanced and hellish to complete, is it even fun anymore? What's the point? I'm sorry, but when most of your players have no idea how to even begin to solve your platforming puzzles, let alone the mechanical skills needed to execute them, and have to rely on in-game-provided cheats to have any hope of beating your content, that's going a step too far in my personal opinion. Moreover, because these stages are so challenging and often long, they quickly devolve into a frustrating cycle that forces players to engage in a trial-and-error gameplay loop that does nothing but infuriate them and increases burnout. I love hard games, but this is simply too much. 

[h3] My Final Thoughts [/h3]

Aside from those two criticisms, all in all, I loved Celeste and thoroughly enjoyed my time with it to summit and back. For an indie studio, Maddy Makes Games had achieved success that most teams can only dream of, and they did it all while laying their hearts on the table and, with grits, delivered us one of the finest and most memorable platformers of all time. Celeste is a genuine masterpiece, and I couldn't end my review without claiming it otherwise. It was a magical experience, one I won't soon forget.

This is the best game I have ever played. Please, play it, and also play mods for it, because most of them are just as good. I'm on my first hundreds of hours, and probably will never stop! If you have actually read all of this, I wish you the best of days! <3

150489494.review:
When playing Celeste, you will be hit by the following conundrum:

"Celeste is intended to be a challenging and rewarding experience. If the default game proves inaccessible to you, we hope that you can still find that experience with Assist Mode."

This option allows you to turn on several cheats, and is apparently an intended way to play the game. Therefore, in Celeste, you are asked to play a (by reputation) mechanically difficult game where the mechanical difficulty is not essential to the experience. As such, I will not subject myself to it, nor should you. Go watch a YouTube playthrough or something, if the story interests you. If you want a platformer whose intended experience is to be played, Super Meat Boy and VVVVVV are fantastic.

[h1]I do not know where to begin.[/h1]

I bought this game in my platformer streak.
I liked the idea of long interconnected stages in metroidvanias, but I wanted something new.
I wanted to play a sole platformer, and Celeste was exactly that.

Long story short, I loved this game.
It has a special place in my heart.

I played through the whole game, collected every red berry, and went through all B and C sides.
But Farewell broke me. I used assist mode to get through it and get 100% achievement completion. It's a single-player game, but I still felt defeated.

At the time of writing this, I finally made it through Farewell and got the Wow achievement in the legitimate way. It is a memorable mark of self-improvement and overcoming your weaknesses.

Celeste gives you exactly that. This is what the game is about. This is why it's such a masterpiece.

[h2] REVIEW [/h2]
I loved this. The whole game is beautiful from start to finish, it is legitimately a piece of art. The gameplay and story are both amazing with the story being a surprise to me as I was not expecting to enjoy it that much. Each level feels unique and you can feel a sense of progression as you play and get better ultimately paying off in the end with a huge sense of accomplishment! I think anyone who wants to challenge themselves but still enjoy the whole experience should try this game for sure! I give it a [b]9/10[/b]

[h2] HIGHLIGHTS [/h2]
[list]
    [*][b]THE ART[/b] - The art in this game is stunning. From the masterful pixel art in the sprites and environments to the adorable hand drawn style of art for the dialogue its just perfect! 
    [*][b]THE STORY[/b] - Going into Celeste I was expecting great game-play and art but what i was not expecting was a beautiful story with a very relatable and deep message behind it.
    [*][b]THE GAME-PLAY[/b] - Its just perfect! Each new mechanic fits in with the last yet provides something new and it really feels like every section was deliberate and meticulously planned out to be a fun experience to figure out the almost puzzle like aspect to it and then execute the timing and precision, its the perfect level of difficulty with being challenging but not annoyingly difficult.
    [*][b]THE MUSIC[/b] - It's beautiful, each track fits the atmosphere and vibe of the level and can go from a lovely, slow melody to an intense and inspiring rhythm! It's just the cherry on top for this masterpiece of a game!
[/list]

150098961.review:
I can't recommend Celeste enough. A delightful, charming, heartwarming and the most challenging 2D platformer I ever laid my eyes on. With a surprisingly gorgeous pixel art, sublime soundtrack and a simple, yet incredibly heartfelt story about personal growth in many different ways, it's a must recommend to everyone.

"But what about the high difficulty level?"

The game accomodates to several different skill levels and while on a 100% completion save file collecting every collectible (which thankfully, are just for the flex points) you would need to become a hardened platformer veteran, the most important part of the game, which is Madeline's Journey and the main levels are acessible to all, be it by default or through assist mode, allowing to extend your safety net even further if for any reason the challenge prove to be unsurmountable for any particular reason. I do advise on exercising some restraint with Assist mode, as overcoming difficult odds are a part of Celeste's theme, so my honest recommendation is that you use Assist mode in order to set the challenge level to something you can tackle, rather than to completely vanquish it.

It's a delightful game. I never got 100% completion with the extra hard collectibles, but that's fine. I got as far as I did, maybe I'll go further later, maybe not. Both scenarios are ok. This is my journey, just like Madeline has hers.

I wish anyone who decides to buy this game a happy climbing and I see you on the top!

150097468.review:
I know I'm a few years late to the party, but I was recently recommended this game via a WoW guildie and about 6(?) weeks ago decided to give it a try. I can honestly say this is one of the best platformers I've ever played. The progression of difficulty, even on the A sides, is just something I've rarely seen before. (Maybe I need to play more games..)

I remember so many instances of thinking 3A was impossible, then moving on and thinking 7A was impossible, that I'd never beat 8A, etc. Then thinking I'd never even try the B sides, but going back and collecting all of the strawberries I had missed thinking "and I thought this was hard". Then, getting through 2B and thinking "well maybe just a couple more, but surely not 6-8B". Then slogging through 7 and 8B just because I wanted to see the C sides, then realizing how short those were decided to grind for those and so many deaths later, I did it! 7C might be the single hardest thing I've done in gaming. So insanely frustrating but immense release at finally getting to that last meadow. 

Celeste strikes such a balance of skill for all levels, depending on what your goals are. I've barely experimented with assist mode, but it seems to be such a smart way of helping people progress through tough parts of the game if desired.

And last but definitely not least, the music/soundtrack is one of the best I've heard. I would frequently just let Madeline sit at whatever room I was in non-paused and listen to the music while I worked. It's that good. 

This is one of the best games I've ever played.

149330188.review:
Celeste is a very forgiving but difficult platformer, that relies heavily on mastering execution.
Within that framework lies an emotionally captivating plot about depression and identity, that is not laid on very thick, but may not resonate with everyone. If you are here for the mechanics alone, you will still get a full game, but if you are not into the gameplay, then the story will not save your enjoyment.
If you die on a screen you respawn on the screen and you have no threat of being sent back earlier in the level, all the collectables are optional and there are multiple points where you can opt out of the game, while feeling accomplished.
If you have motor troubles, then the game allows you to adjust many settings to make it easier for you, including game speed, additional jumps and air dashes or even full invincibility, though your mileage will vary on how much these will help you in enjoying the game.
You will definitely like this if you enjoy execution heavy platformers.
You will not enjoy this if you do not enjoy platformers at all.

This game is really heartwarming in so many aspects, from the story to the visuals put through important moments.
Celeste is what i would call the "perfect" game for people that enjoy 2D platformers containing quick thinking areas and some harder difficulty sections, and the movement once performed correctly is so fluid and later chapters expand on these mechanics.
The visual representation for the areas in this game are phenomenal, especially farewell (chapter 9) as some many areas of emotion and challenge are lit up through the design and movement of your surroundings.
These points also lean towards the music as well, being produced by Lena Raine it is beautifully composed throughout every chapter from start to finish.
The modding scene for celeste is also incredible, strawberry jam, a collab between many celeste creators contains many levels of different gameplay, gimmicks and difficulty with 5 lobby's of difficulty that are all accessible, this mod is professionally made and serves as a great post-main game experience for people who want more from celeste's mechanics and visuals.
This game really is something and if you want a game with incredibly fluid/fast movement and a heartwarming story then celeste is your game.

149123095.review:
I love 'Platformers', never was there a less controversial statement spoken, everyone hearts platformers! It’s what we grew up on whether it be Sonic, Spyro, Zelda, Crash, Jak & Dax, Rach & Clank or the timeless Don himself Mario. The joy of finally scaling that challenging level & grabbing that dopamine doused hidden shiny gives us that feeling of YIPPEE! It’s that essence which takes us back to the joy of it all, without ever being consciously sentimental, quite the opposite, it’s gaming in the moment & there’s no time to indulge in mawkish overthinking because I have to double dash onto that bouncy-bounce so I can roll under the spiky-spikes to get the golden thingy!!!, if that sentence is gibberish to you then you need to rediscover all that is good & pure in the world.

First impressions: It welcomed me in with luminous twilight tones, fantastical purple motif, idiosyncratic pixel pals ...then once it had me seduced it encouraged me through cut-scenes and early challenges to believe that I WILL find a way to push through when needed, so I accepted I may not get things the first time but I do pride myself on resilience & being able to work stuff out, the challenge was afoot. Celeste was not a purchase I jumped into, I didn’t want to be too frustrated by the trial & error drudgery or solely reaction based game-play but it balanced in puzzler aspects really well, I will invest time in a good 'chin-scratcher' (if it's done cleverly) which I did with Celeste.

So I reached the peak of the mountain in Celeste I took the honour of a heartfelt sigh, switched to speakers to hear the soundtrack one last time then lent back in my chair to watch those rolling credits. After watching cut-scene Madeline hop back down that pixel-ed peak only to make a strawberry pie for the 3 NPCs out of the hidden strawberries I collected throughout the game, I thought to myself I’ll sleep well tonight, goodnight Celeste.

THE END....now I'm hooked on the last bonus level-- chapter 9 - and I can see it's going to be crazy...I am by nature a casual gamer I am not a ‘completionist’, but with a few games (Celeste is one of those) I want to go back and scale that mountain! Why?... 'Because it's there' and it's a fun challenge.

The best Precision platformer with nothing else getting close for me.

Celeste's movement feels absolutely perfect. Sure the game's difficulty is kicking my teeth in, but at least it's my fault when I fail. Actually fairly approachable until you hit the credits, it's the postgame where Celeste truly shines, hitting you with new nuances and moves to the movement over and over.

The game does not lack in content, taking me lke 16 hours to 100% with more content available through the modding community. I highly recommend checking out the Strawberry Jam mod as it's an extremely impressive piece of content.

I really like the story, Madeline having to get over her anxiety to climb the mountain. Even with difficult things there's no shame in needing help, reach out to people around you, to friends. Enable assist mode if you need to. Your accomplishment will still be that, an accomplishment.

I love the music, it's amazing. Listen to it, purchase it, listen to it more.

This is my new comfort game.
Celeste is a difficult game, but I was never frustrated because it's not a very punishing game. You don't lose much progress from your hundreds of deaths.
The first few chapters were really fun, but looking back they sort of felt like tutorials. Not in a hand holding way, but because it's really just where you get all the muscle memory down and get the basics down.
Then the last couple chapters were easily some of the most rewarding experiences I've ever had in a video game.
If you plan on playing this game with a keyboard like I did, here's something I did about halfway through that I'd really recommend: Set WASD to be your movement, all 4 arrow keys to be dash, and in advanced have the arrow keys as dash only movement. That way, you can be moving one way and dash in another. It was a little weird at first but after about an hour it really helped.

Celeste Objective Review
-----
Gameplay: 10/10, game is fair, encouraging, and rewarding
Replayability: 10/10 (I played through it twice)
Story: 9.5/10, immersive in parts; ultimately simple but done well
Originality: 7/10, predecessor of Super Meat Boy
Presentation and quality: 10/10
Music: 10/10, same producer who scored music for Minecraft, so obvs great
Visuals: 10/10
Depth: 8/10, lots of hidden stuff and difficult achievements to get
Emotion: 8/10, I guess it's capped in this regard because the feeling of overcoming anxiety is limited in magnitude compared to grief, for example
Ending: 9/10, true ending is great, only reason not 10 because it isn't a super natural ending considering the devs added it as dlc later on
Price: 9/10, it's 18 quid which is a fair bit when you consider something like Hollow Knight which is only 11 but has much more depth and playtime
-----
Overall: 90.5/100

148474003.review:
When I say that this game had a big impact on me, I mean it. It's surprising really, how much emotion a platformer can evoke. I mean, I wasn't initially expecting terribly much when I began playing as this was my first platformer and I got it on sale but I was pleasantly surprised.

Whether it was the gorgeous visuals of this game to the amazing music that I find myself listening to even today to even the game's mechanics which I found weren't too bad on PC, I had an amazing time. While yes, some sections of the game were difficult to push through (looking at you Chapter 3), this game teaches you that perseverance and optimism can get you through everything. Even though I still haven't finished the game entirely as I work through Farewell, I keep finding these sentiments expressing themselves through each room I get through. I step into a room and look at it as a daunting hill to climb, but with a few deaths and learning from each one I find myself passing through to continue my journey.

For those of you who might be scared of this infamously difficult platformer, don't be. I won't be shy to admit it, but I used the assist mode that this game offers and it helped me so much. You can use it to help work through a room at your own pace and allow you to practice before doing it for real with the default settings. I especially used assist mode when trying to figure out how to mechanically make my way through extra content for the game, and it allowed me to be better prepared in terms of timing and mechanics and prevented me from simply calling it quits and moving on from the game.

I highly suggest you play this game if you haven't already, and I'll update this review when I do manage to beat Farewell. 101 hours in and I still haven't beat it, but it's been worth the time I've invested in this game. While I may find myself playing another game once I make this a perfect game, I don't think I'll ever quite be able to bid this game farewell.

148472383.review:
[h1][b]Celeste embodies everything I've ever wanted in a platformer[/b][/h1]
Of the many platformers I've ever had the pleasure of playing, this is without a doubt one of the best. 

Celeste continuously caught me off guard and presented new obstacles, ranging from the basic mechanics of jumping and climbing to the complicated techniques of dashing, wall-jumping, and using surrounding objects. With each chapter, the game introduces new mechanics and elements keeping the experience intriguing and new. The gameplay is made diverse thanks to this progressive approach, which also makes sure that the player is challenged and improved as the game progresses. It shows the game's careful design and attention that keeps the game from getting stale.

I won't go over much about the story but in short Celeste revolves around Madeline overcoming her own personal issues as a direct parallel to her also climbing a mountain

In essence, Celeste is a game that makes players adapt and overcome challenges. It invites them to explore its intricately designed levels, discover new mechanics, and push their skills to the limit. With each new chapter there is something new. Celeste provided me a rewarding and empowering experience. It's a game that embodies the essence of struggle and triumph, making it a truly exceptional and unforgettable platformer.

148414802.review:
I'm not good at expressing myself through words, but for this game I have to try. 

The reason I bought this game was because I had just finished 101%ing Pizza Tower, and I was looking for a new game to play. I remembered hearing something about Celeste, so I thought I'd check it out. At the time Pizza Tower was my favorite game, and when I downloaded the game, I told myself that no matter what, Pizza Tower was going to remain my favorite game after I played this. 

This game is beautiful. The art and music both go above and beyond, and the gameplay is obviously what makes it so good  and its why people still talk about the game today, but the way Celeste uses its gameplay to empower the story is the thing that I find to be Celeste's biggest strength. The goal of Celeste is to climb a mountain, which is a very difficult task, obviously. But to climb that mountain, the main character, Madeline, has to climb the metaphorical mountain of mental illness. In my case, Celeste was a challenge, and one that I didn't know if I could fulfill. I would have to surpass challenge after challenge, which would be difficult, almost like I was climbing a mountain. But if I wanted to climb Celeste, I'd have to be able to persevere, no matter how difficult it got. Madeline's climb directly parallels the player's; a physical challenge locked behind a mental challenge.

If you ask me, being bad at video games is the best way to experience Celeste. (Being bad at video games and also having the will to persevere, that is)

I beat Celeste in about 1700 deaths, and I completed Celeste in about 17000. As I approached the final room of Farewell, I finally remembered the promise I made to myself at the beginning of the game. And as much as I wanted Pizza Tower to be my favorite game, it really couldn't compare. 

For the love of god, please play this game.

148311936.review:
I don't know what to think about this game, so I had ChatGPT write a review for me as if it was written by the Heavy from TF2.

I must say, this Celeste game is quite the experience! Just like carrying my trusty Sasha, it's a heavy load of a challenge, but also a ton of fun.

First off, the platforming in this game is a real workout, much like lugging around my beloved minigun. The controls are tight and responsive, just like the precision needed to aim Sasha. Climbing those mountains feels like a never-ending battle, but when you reach the summit, the sense of accomplishment is like the satisfaction of a well-timed headshot.

The story, much like the lore in Team Fortress 2, unfolds in unexpected ways and keeps you engaged throughout. You'll find yourself caring about the characters and their struggles, much like we do for our fellow mercenaries.

The pixel art style is quite charming, and the soundtrack is as epic as a Heavy/Medic combo push through the battlefield. The music adds to the adrenaline rush, just like the sound of Sasha's spinning barrels before a showdown.

But be warned, this game can be as punishing as a crit rocket from the enemy Soldier. You'll die a lot, but it's all part of the learning experience. Just like in TF2, you keep coming back for more, honing your skills, and feeling more powerful with each attempt.

In conclusion, Celeste is a game that's both challenging and rewarding, just like the life of a Heavy. If you're ready to take on a mountain of a challenge and appreciate a well-crafted indie game, give Celeste a try. It's like a Sandvich for your gaming soul, and I guarantee you won't be disappointed.

148271716.review:
Ignore my playtime, I used to work aboard a cruise ship and as such I played almost the whole main story in offline mode.

As far as the gameplay is concerned, this game is tight, and well put together. She feels rather weighty in the air which I found annoying at first but after going through the game I can safely say that it was the proper gravity level for the puzzle like platforming this game offers. Each story mission introduces new mechanics that don't overstay their welcome as each mission ends almost immediately after you say "This Again?"

The graphics are 16 bit style and I think it meshes with the game play well. For story segments, chat bubbles between characters have HD sprite work and all the characters have unique enough designs for it to be obvious which speech bubble is correlated to which 16 bit sprite on screen. I will say though that the scenes that are presented during cut scenes invoke much more vividly beautiful imagery than what the limited 16 bit graphics actually show. Weirdly though, the menus feature a 3d rendering of the mountain that you climb in the game, which I personally didn't care much for. It always takes me off guard when I see it.

The game's story has gained alot of praise for being an accurate representation of what crippling anxiety and split personality disorder is like. I have neither of these things so for me the story wasn't that personally engaging and most importantly I feel it massively contradicts what is presented during game play. During game play the main protagonist is doing physical stunts of acrobatics around very VERY dangerous environments, one would imagine that an individual doing these things would need to be quite brave. But the moment a cut scene starts we are introduced to a protagonist that seems to be barely keeping it together. It's very jarring to say the least. But again, I don't have the afflictions the main protagonist does so perhaps that's just what a day in the life of someone with anxiety is like. Odd though.

Overall I would say the game is absolutely worth your money for the game play alone. Not only does it feature a campaign of decent length, but there is also end game content that I'm certain tests the capabilities of the most hardcore players.

148250160.review:
The main game is really fun. The controls feel great, challenges are fair and interesting, and the secrets are usually fun to hunt down.

The B and C sides are more of the same platforming goodness the story had to offer, but way more challenging and really require you to explore the level gimmicks.

However, my enjoyment ends with the DLC chapter Farewell. This chapter takes everything great about the game and tosses it away. The game introduces some advanced movement techniques that do not feel consistent or fun to pull off, making every screen feel luck based rather than skill based. I beat the A, B, and C sides fairly, but will fully admit to using invincibility to cheat this chapter as it did not feel fun or fair to me.

Play the base game, it is amazing and does an excellent job blending the story with gameplay in a way most games could only dream of doing.

If you want more, give the harder difficulty stages a shot and see how far you can go! My limit was the DLC chapter, but everyone besides for me and a handful of people seem to love it, so maybe you will too.

148248929.review:
TRANSGENDER??????? TRANS RIGHTS?????

ok serious.
I started playing Celeste on the Pico-8 version, which I would play in school after finishing my work in compsci (bc it was a really easy class) and I got SUPER into it to the point where I did a run that was completely deathless, except for the last level (I hate that last level)
A year or so later, I bought the full game. Getting used to the new grab mechanic that I hadn't had before took me a little bit, but it really wasn't a hassle. Getting through the first stage was super similar to the pico-8 version (I'm assuming that it was on purpose) so I got through it well (and my current time on it is 1:58.541, which i am very proud of) but every stage after that added more new and unique mechanics.

I'd be lying if I said that it wasn't insanely difficult, because it was, but I'd also be lying if I said it wasn't easy to grasp. As I've heard someone (I don't remember who) say, "Celeste is the hardest game that everybody can play" and that's absolutely true. The mechanics are introduced well, and the level's aren't designed to be hard for the sake of being hard. I think the best was to describe it is "incredibly challenging, but not hard."

Because of how well the game is designed and how well it teaches you the controls and mechanics, when you die, you don't blame the game for being "stupid and too hard", you know that you made the mistake, and you know how to fix it, you just need to practice it and try again. You're always the one responsible for messing up, which actually makes it a lot easier not to rage quit or anything like that. The fact that I know how to fix the mistake that just killed me and I just need to retry, instead of the death just being because the game is needlessly hard, makes it a lot more enjoyable (who knew?) The accessibility options are also wonderful! Even though I don't need it, I feel like a colorblind option would be a good accessibility addition, but all the other accessibility options are phenomenal, and make sure that pretty much anyone can pick up Celeste and start playing!

Lastly, I want to mention the more advanced mechanics. I'm not a Celeste speedrunner, as much as I like running the first (and sometimes second) stage, I could never run the whole game. However, I've watched SO many Celeste speedruns and TASes (mostly from diff GDQs, if you want, 
[url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLufeepXLMvnNZsgGoo316Eem0QvnY1Prw]here's a playlist of some of my fave Celeste speedrun vids[/url]) But the fact that there are so many difficult and advanced mechanics, some that spawned from bugs that the (amazing) devs turned into features, is SO so cool. Especially because you don't need to know these advanced mechanics to play. As long as you grasp the basics, you're good! But if you wanna try some other stuff, you can learn these! You also get really proud of yourself when you successfully pull of one of these tricks. I know the first time i did a hyperdash I was pretty proud, and I was ECSTATIC the one (and only) time I successfully did a demodash to skip that area in the hotel. 

tl;dr, Celeste is an INCREDIBLE game, and is WONDERFUL for anyone trying to get into precision platformers, or just wanting a cool game to play. The story is great, the music is amazing (shouts out Lena Raine), the dev team is super cool, the community is the absolute greatest, and, most importantly, the game is so SO fun.

Trans rights, long live Archie, and play Celeste!!!!

148161898.review:
Celeste: A Tale of Unparalleled Beauty and Gameplay Challenges

Celeste is undoubtedly a remarkable game, a mesmerizing concoction of beauty, and on the flip side, gameplay challenges. Let's dive into the details of this awe-inspiring journey.

A Symphony of Sensory Delights:
Where Celeste truly shines is in its aesthetics and audio. The music is pure magic; I find myself listening to some of these tracks even outside the game. The "remix" or B-C sides of the soundtrack are no less masterful, adding an extra layer to the audio experience. The pixel-style graphics are both fitting and visually pleasing. The animations, especially Madeline's idle quirks like sneezing, are charming and demonstrate the developers' keen attention to detail.

A Heartfelt Story:
The narrative woven into Celeste is a masterpiece in its own right. It carries a beautiful message and delivers it in a relatable and touching manner. The story is a poignant reminder of the struggles and triumphs in our own lives.

Gameplay Dilemmas:
Now, the gameplay is where Celeste stumbles just a bit. If it were solely the main chapters, Celeste would be near flawless. However, the B-C sides, Core, and Farewell chapters introduce challenges that, while commendable for their ambition, sometimes teeter on the edge of frustration.

Level-Design Quirks:
Even within the main chapters, there are occasional hurdles. For instance, Chapter 3 is oddly more challenging than the following chapter, primarily due to its many quick-moving obstacles. Moreover, while the game offers a sense of freedom in movement, certain objects and screens feel out of place and disrupt the flow, especially in Core and Farewell. It's a bit like a puzzle where some pieces just don't fit.

Unintended Freedom and Cheesiness:
Celeste offers a considerable degree of freedom in how you navigate its levels. However, it sometimes feels like a design oversight rather than intentional choice. The term "cheese," borrowed from the Mario Maker community, is apt here. While some may argue it's a design feature, I can't help but wonder if it's a result of carelessness or poor level design.

Gameplay Timing and Respawns:
Celeste's timed elements can be frustrating. It's not about simply holding right; there's strategy involved. However, waiting half a second after each respawn can accumulate into tedious downtime. This issue becomes even more evident when searching for B-C side cassette tapes, where the timing doesn't reset upon death, leading to unpredictable waiting periods.

Secrets and Their Challenges:
The crystal hearts are an engaging and rewarding element, encouraging exploration and careful observation. However, there's room for improvement. For instance, the solution to the Chapter 1 heart becomes a memory test several chapters later, which isn't ideal. Some secrets, particularly the challenging ones, lack proper indications, leading players to miss them entirely.

A Mountain of Difficulty:
Celeste's difficulty spikes significantly in the B-C sides, Core, and Farewell chapters. While challenging games are enjoyable, the steepness of the curve often crosses the line into unfairness. It transforms the experience into a grind and muscle memory exercise rather than enjoyable gameplay.

A Summit of Main Game:
The main part of the game, Madeline's journey to the summit, collecting 175 strawberries and crystal hearts, is easily recommendable. It presents a balanced, challenging, and enjoyable experience that tests your skills without crossing into frustration too much.

Extra Content: The Double-Edged Sword:
Conversely, the B-C sides and Farewell are far less recommendable, in my opinion. They introduce a level of difficulty that transitions from fun to constant frustration. The additional story in Core and Farewell feels somewhat forced and doesn't quite resonate with Madeline's initial mountain-climbing motivation.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Celeste is a gem with its main game and a visual and auditory masterpiece. Its narrative and visuals are emotionally resonant, but the journey becomes a touch turbulent in the extra content. Celeste delivers an incredible experience, but it's in the B-C sides, Core, and Farewell that it sometimes struggles to maintain its balance.

Celeste stands as an essential play for those seeking a poignant narrative, fantastic music, and challenging but fair gameplay. It's a shining example of the incredible experiences that indie games can offer. While it may not reach the grandeur of a AAA title, it's a testament to the creativity and talent within the indie game development community. Celeste may not be a total masterpiece, but it proudly wears the badge of indie excellence.

148017864.review: I bought Celeste quite a while ago, (maybe even over a year ago), and only got up to about chapter 3 because I got bored. I recently came back to it, as Spotify had been recommending me the games music, not to mention I had become a fan of Lena Raine since initially purchasing the game. Coming back to Celeste was a GREAT decision. I must have gained a newborn appreciation for games out of nowhere, because the platforming felt great and very responsive, the level design was amazing, the levels were difficult to both interpret and play through, but not so difficult that it was frustrating or made you want to give up. To me, Celeste isn't a game about simply climbing a mountain, it is a game that delves into the ideas of anxiety and depression, which are portrayed perfectly by Madeline and Badeline. The portrayal of these ideas just felt extremely realistic, and easy to digest, I'm not quite sure how to explain it. The difficulty of the game, and ESPECIALLY the difficulty of chapter 9 makes you really feel like you are overcoming those anxieties. Lastly, but definitely not last, THE MUSIC. Every bit of music fits in so well with the corresponding section of the game. Lena Raine is an amazing musician, and her music in Celeste is in my opinion, her best work. It accompanies so much emotion and detail, not seen much in video game music. One thing that I noticed and really like, is that Madeline seems to have a leitmotif that represents her, and is present in almost every single song in the soundtrack, but fits in every time and is somehow not overused at all. I also noticed that some of the characters were represented by certain instruments, (Piano: Madeline, Synth: Badeline, Violin: Granny/crow) All of which I feel fit extremely well. I have an in-depth review for Farewell's music but this is already getting kind of long. Overall, Celeste is an amazing game, probably in my top 5 games OAT, and so is the soundtrack. I highly recommend it even if you suck at platformers. The feeling of accomplishment of passing a hard screen after hundreds of deaths is like no other.

147842672.review:
[h1] Celeste is a story-rich, difficult platforming challenge which is definitely worth the patience. [/h1]

Celeste is presented as a high-difficulty platformer with smooth controls and barely fair level design. The way it's designed makes every challenge seem possible if you give it enough time to master it, and it's forgiving checkpoint system keeps this process steady.
Every screen is a possibility to show the skills gained from previous encounters, improve upon them, or gain a further understanding on how the game operates.
The struggle of learning to overcome these challenges is also definitely expressed inside the story, being about the overcoming of ones fears by climbing a mountain by embrancing them and accepting themselves thanks to your loved ones around you.
Or in case of the final chapter (spoilers for the story),[spoiler] dealing with the grief of losing someone you love, finding a way to cope with the fact and ultimately accepting the reality and finding support in those around you, remembering the good times rather than rotting in the sadness. [/spoiler]
It would be an understatement to say that Celeste's storytelling is good, with compelling characters and a down to earth meaning, and despite that my memory of the details is fuzzy from the last time I played it, I still recall enjoying myself every step of the way, learning from my mistakes and being able to overcome those difficult challenges.

[h2] 100% [/h2]

100%ing Celeste is quite the ordeal. Although most achievement you get while playing the game normally (Finishing the chapters, [spoiler] finishing the B-Sides and C-Sides [/spoiler]), the ones which you have to go out of your way to get are fairly challenging but you can finish them with enough practice (Getting every Strawberry, Receiving a 1-up and[spoiler] getting the WOW berry in the Farewell Chapter. [/spoiler])

[h2] Recomendation [/h2]

I would recommend Celeste only if you're willing to partake in a challenging platformer and give it the time to master it and get through it to the end. And even if you're not into that sort of thing, the game allows for a multitude of accesibily options to help make the gameplay easier, so you can also get into it solely for the story without needing to worry about being good at platformers.

[h3] TL;DR [/h3]
[olist]
    [*]Challening platformer with compelling story.
    [*]Decently hard achievements due to base game already being difficult.
    [*]Recommended.
[/olist]

147835595.review:
This is a review a long time coming, I absolutely love this game. Celeste is a special game to me in many ways and is one that I spent time playing both on and off steam. If you are at all a fan of platformer type games with engaging story I highly recommend you pick up a copy for yourself. 

What does the game do well?

- The Gameplay -  
The controls and mechanics are tight and easy to learn but present a nice challenge to master and use efficiently and effectively. After putting well over 60 hours (mostly off steam) I died a lot in this game, however never due to the gameplay/mechanics. I was always able to point to something that I could do/time better on my end and after all that time I can fly through and really enjoy the levels.

- The Art - 
Celeste's pixel art is some of my favorite, though at times quite simplistic, the backgrounds the details, the energy, and oh my gosh the colors are perfect. This game is cute and during the down time sections, incredibly soothing. 

- The Music - 
Lena Raine, need I say more? 10/10

- The Story - 
Celeste's story is really one about your own journey and overcoming the limitations you place on yourself. It's uplifting and realistic in a way I haven't seen in many games. It's mature but doesn't always take itself too seriously. Also the breathing scene with the feather (you'll know when you see it) is beyond amazing and something I now use in my daily life. The gameplay is definitely the focus here but they made sure not to pull their punches with the story and I love it. 

--- TL;DR ---
The game is overwhelmingly positive for a reason. If you like platformer games that challenge you without being too punishing, and with optional harder levels, Celeste is a MUST. I would honestly buy this game for more that the $19.99 full price tag, it's really incredible. Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy either on sale or not and just try it out. 

Price: $19.99
Time: 60+ hours (multiple platforms)
Recommend: Yes

147669603.review: I bought Celeste quite a while ago, (maybe even over a year ago), and only got up to about chapter 3 because I got bored. I recently came back to it, as Spotify had been recommending me the games music, not to mention I had become a fan of Lena Raine since initially purchasing the game. Coming back to Celeste was a GREAT decision. I must have gained a newborn appreciation for games out of nowhere, because the platforming felt great and very responsive, the level design was amazing, the levels were difficult to both interpret and play through, but not so difficult that it was frustrating or made you want to give up. To me, Celeste isn't a game about simply climbing a mountain, it is a game that delves into the ideas of anxiety and depression, which are portrayed perfectly by Madeline and Badeline. The portrayal of these ideas just felt extremely realistic, and easy to digest, I'm not quite sure how to explain it. The difficulty of the game, and ESPECIALLY the difficulty of chapter 9 makes you really feel like you are overcoming those anxieties. Lastly, but definitely not last, THE MUSIC. Every bit of music fits in so well with the corresponding section of the game. Lena Raine is an amazing musician, and her music in Celeste is in my opinion, her best work. It accompanies so much emotion and detail, not seen much in video game music. One thing that I noticed and really like, is that Madeline seems to have a leitmotif that represents her, and is present in almost every single song in the soundtrack, but fits in every time and is somehow not overused at all. I also noticed that some of the characters were represented by certain instruments, (Piano: Madeline, Synth: Badeline, Violin: Granny/crow) All of which I feel fit extremely well. I have an in-depth review for Farewell's music but this is already getting kind of long. Overall, Celeste is an amazing game, probably in my top 5 games OAT, and so is the soundtrack. I highly recommend it even if you suck at platformers. The feeling of accomplishment of passing a hard screen after hundreds of deaths is like no other.

147468592.review:
Celeste, es un juego especial.

Desde su simple pero intrigante y bien cuidada historia, hasta su hermoso estilo artístico basado en pixeles, difícil pero adictivo gameplay, y espectacular banda sonora que acompaña al jugador a lo largo del juego, Celeste se presenta como un plataformero 2D "hardcore", con cientos de pantallas diferentes para explorar, en la que se narra una de las etapas de la vida de Madeline, la protagonista, a modo de una historia de autosuperación.

Desde el inicio, Celeste te acompaña durante los primeros niveles explicando los (pocos) controles que el jugador utilizará a lo largo del juego, abriendo con cada nivel la posibilidad de mejorar la maestría de estos para mejorar o descubrir nuevas mecánicas del juego. La dificultad del juego escala notablemente, así como la implicación del jugador en el juego y la historia que lo envuelve. Esto dio lugar a uno de los momentos más únicos y especiales que he tenido como jugador en mi vida.
Celeste tiene todo lo que un buen juego de su genero puede tener. Unos gráficos y estilo artístico totalmente creados a mano, por amor al arte de los pixeles. Una narrativa dulce y cautivadora, con la que el jugador puede empatizar, si no sentirse cercano a los sucesos que ocurren, siendo un reflejo de lo que uno puede haber pasado, o estar pasando. Una dificultad realmente justa, en la que el jugador puede sentirse en la amplia mayoría de casos culpable de todos los errores que comete, dándole la capacidad de mejorar y mejorar hasta lograr pasar una pantalla. Una banda sonora impecable, que se hará hueco en tu memoria por el resto de los tiempos, junto a la historia que está adherida, y junto a la experiencia que uno pasa cuando juega Celeste.
Con numerosas pantallas, coleccionables, rutas ocultas y peligrosas, e incluso mundos totalmente completos con caras B y caras C por cada nivel para aquellos que buscan la excelencia y la maestría de sus habilidades, Celeste no se queda atrás en lo que es contenido. Además, a lo largo del tiempo se han ido implementado DLCs, ahora gratis para todos los usuarios, que incluyen hasta 2 nuevos mundos, cada uno con sus rutas ocultas, coleccionables y caras B y C. Eso es, también, sin contar la increíble y acogedora comunidad de desarrolladores que siguen creando contenido personalizado adicional para el juego.
En Celeste, solo el jugador puede poner donde está el final. Uno puede terminar la campaña principal y darse por satisfecho, o puede atreverse a ir a los mundos posteriores, mucho más difíciles, pero cuya única recompensa, la de autosuficiencia, autodeterminación y orgullo por uno mismo al llegar a la pantalla final, es lo suficiente como para empujar la valentía del jugador a seguir fallando, volviendolo a intentar, hasta poder batir cualquier cosa que se le enfrente.

Finalmente, la historia de Celeste, potenciada por su banda sonora y conducida por su gameplay difícil y adictivo, es lo que hace brillar a este juego. Uno nunca se da por satisfecho y siempre siente la necesidad de poder mejorar con cada pantalla, mundo o cara. La historia de Celeste habla de la autodeterminación, el orgullo de uno mismo, la valentía para afrontar los miedos de uno, y, sobre todo, la persistencia y el control de uno mismo para lograr siempre salir mejor que antes. Habla de afrontar la depresión, el miedo y la baja autoestima, la no confianza de uno mismo y la representación del odio de uno así mismo; Madeline (la protagonista de la historia) es, en muchos casos, un reflejo de la superación personal y es esto mismo lo que se refleja en el jugador cuando este se siente inmerso, cuando es uno con el juego y lo que pretende enseñar.

No todos los juegos son para todo el mundo. Y los plataformeros no son precisamente la excepción. Si acaso, lo contrario. Sin embargo, Celeste pone a tu disposición numerosas herramientas de asistencia para poder transportar la adrenalina, historia, banda sonora y experiencia de juego a todo tipo de jugadores, tanto aquellos con discapacidades, como aquellos que solo pueden permitirse jugar juegos de forma casual, o aquellos con PCs de bajo rendimiento. Es bajo este pretexto y bajo las herramientas de asistencia ofrecidas por los desarrolladores de Celeste, que puedo decir con cierta certeza que Celeste puede llegar a ser un juego para todos.

Es con su diseño artístico, con su banda sonora, con su adictivo y pulido gameplay, y con su gran cuidada y presentada historia que, creo que se puedo afirmar que Celeste es uno de los pocos juegos "perfectos" que uno puede encontrarse en el mundo de los videojuegos, en concreto, en el género de plataformas.

Por lo menos lo suficiente como para no poder sentirme peor después de haber completado el juego en una copia pirata del juego, lo que me hizo indudablemente comprar una copia aquí en Steam, por respeto a los desarrolladores y la altísima calidad de este juego.

Definitivamente, Celeste es un juego especial. Un juego con el potencial de cambiar la percepción de las personas, e incluso la vida de otras; como es mi caso, y la de otros muchos más.

the main story of this game is very fun to play through. seeing the main character, madeline, attempt to climb Mt. Celeste while battling her own personified emotions makes for a very interesting plot.

However, after the main plot, the game starts getting a bit boring (at least, i find it to). it has extra levels and achievements, but they are all not very beginner-friendly (which is expected from a game like this). 

Celeste is a game that helps you learn and encourages you to go out of your comfort zone by challenging yourself. The final chapter is easily harder than Hollow Knight's Path of Pain. This isn't a bad thing, just something to keep in mind before downloading. If you want a more casual experience, don't go for this game

Despite what I said about the game not being very replayable, it is genuinely an amazing experience the first time 'round and i highly recommend this.

147217535.review:
¡Celeste es una verdadera joya que merece ser destacada, incluso después de solo 6 horas de juego! Aunque mi experiencia en este título es limitada, y no creo que continue jugando, no puedo evitar maravillarme ante su belleza y encanto.

Desde el momento en que te adentras en el mundo de Celeste, te verás inmerso en una experiencia de juego que destila amor y cuidado en cada píxel. Sus gráficos pixelados, aunque simples, logran transmitir una sensación de calidez y nostalgia que te atrapa de inmediato. Los colores y el diseño de los escenarios son simplemente impresionantes, creando un ambiente cautivador que te sumerge en la historia.

La música en Celeste merece una mención especial. La banda sonora es una obra maestra que complementa perfectamente la experiencia de juego. Cada nota musical te sumerge aún más en la narrativa emocional de la protagonista y te conecta profundamente con su viaje personal.

La jugabilidad es excepcional. Los controles son precisos y receptivos, lo que te permite realizar movimientos y acrobacias con facilidad. A medida que avanzas en los desafiantes niveles de plataformas, la sensación de logro al superar obstáculos y resolver acertijos es gratificante y adictiva.

La historia de Celeste, que sigue el viaje de Madeline en busca de autodescubrimiento y superación personal, es conmovedora y te hace sentir identificado con los desafíos y obstáculos de la vida real. Aunque mi tiempo en el juego es limitado, puedo ver claramente que esta narrativa está cuidadosamente tejida en la jugabilidad y los escenarios, lo que crea una experiencia verdaderamente inmersiva.

En resumen, y repito, aunque solo llevo 6 horas de juego en Celeste y no he completado muchos de los logros, puedo decir sin duda que es un título precioso que merece toda la atención que recibe. Su belleza visual y musical, junto con su jugabilidad desafiante y su historia conmovedora, lo convierten en una experiencia de juego que no querrás perderte. ¡Celeste es una obra maestra en todos los sentidos por mas que no me gusten los juegos de plataformas!

147144409.review:
Game has great things but I bounced off hard. Ironically if you have anxiety problems this game might not be for you. Precise 2D platforming has never been my strong suit, but I've played similar titles to the end no problem. This game ultimately frustrated me more than it entertained me, and in a world with plenty of other games to play, that meant this was one of the few games in the last 10 years I dropped without finishing.

Most impressive thing the game has going are the controls, the devs really took a simple system and milked it for all it was worth. Each added layer of complexity makes for better puzzles that make sense. The problem is replicating perfect movements over and over for me gets frustrating, and when you finish a hard section I'm sure most will feel accomplished, I was just glad it was over. Still, even then I could always see what I did wrong. Props on that.

I like Madeline and think her struggle with anxiety and wanting to move forward is compelling. I just hate all of the other characters. I think Theo sucks, especially as a comic relief character, he has greater depths at points but ultimately annoys the hell out of me. The entire hotel section with Mr. Oshiro got really grating over time, and it went on far too long. The old woman is a jerk.

A mix of frustration with gameplay and general dislike of most of the cast just made me not care about the rest of the story.

Music is good, but gets repetitive to the point where I had to turn it off at points.

Level design is good for the most part, but there are points you can just tell the game devs made a platform a little too short or put some pitfall or spike trap in one place just to mess with you. Each stage goes on waaaaaaaaaaaaaay too long. There are rooms where perfection is required for 4-5+ minutes and that's just not fun in a game where one false move means death.

This is a good game, its really just not for me. Maybe one day I'll come back and tackle the mountain, I'd just rather be having fun doing it.

146918982.review: After playing for two and a half hours, I don't get the hype and acclaim for this game at all. Yes, the controls are responsive, the music is fine, and a story does kinda exist. I will also say that Celeste, unlike other games of similiar difficulty, is not very punishing or rage-inducing, instead actually being supportive to an extent (which I'll admit is rather refreshing). Also, it does have some obscure mechanics and tricks that may make this game more interesting to speedrunners or those wanting to learn how to speedrun. But that's the extent of my genuine praise for the game, since even the controls are limited and thus problematic (in my opinion) since, at least by default, the dashes can only go in the 8 directions available to a keyboard (which is why this is one of the few platformers where I don't recommend using a controller). In essence, all my complaints really boil down to not finding anything while playing that made it stick out from the pack. While the game isn't broken, there are just so many better alternatives to what I personally experienced with Celeste. Everything that is praised about this game is simply done better elsewhere (in my opinion), and there are some platformers that I consider to be strictly better in every way. For instance, many games out there could correctly claim to have controls that are just as smooth and responsive. Beyond that, most of those games even have more features to the average player! Honestly, it isn't hard to feel responsive when the effective toolset for the majority of players is so limited (despite some complex interactions that can result from them). Furthermore, the supposedly great story isn't very engaging or enthralling at the start either. The game is not as insanely hard as it is made out to be as well. As a completionist, I died more at the beginning due to checking whether the map continued in a direction (looking for secrets/collectibles) than because of any actual mechanical challenge. Simply put, my motivation for playing the game died really quickly after learning that the game was going to continue with pretty much more of the same (except with some subtle variations and a few story elements thrown in). To anyone still interested, I suggest playing the first chapter or two and seeing if you like it. If you do, then continue on knowing that the game will continue giving experiences close to that and enjoy it. For the others like me, I suggest switching to any of the wide variety of more worthy games or other ways to spend your time. TLDR: The gameplay and experience doesn't significantly change much from the first two chapters, so if you are interested in Celeste I would advise giving them a try and basing the decision of whether to continue playing or refund it (if possible) based on how much you enjoy them.

146824485.review:
This is one of the best platformers ever made, well worth it's money, for the reasons listed down:

MECHANICS:
As far as Madeline is concerned, her move set is apparently limited to jumping and dashing, however, those can be used in countless ways, taylored towards casual player  and speedrunners alike. Those mainly stem from conservation of momentum, and make possible moves like hyper / reverse / extended super, wavedashes, and also some about hitbox interactions.  As a result the gameplay seems fun, leaving choise to the player, for a beginner to inch their way forward while advanced players slingshot themselves through the room.
More variation is added through the vast asortment of items Madeline can interract with, which are dependant on the level and keep the game always feeling fresh and push its boudaries for extracting novelty from level design. Everybody can find a favourite from those. The level design is really a strong point here.

GAMEPLAY:
Make no mistake, the game is very difficult, but it always gives the impression that everything can be done eventually with enough practice. That's mainly because it feels very fair, forgiving to the player  through a lot of coyote timings: basically the basic jump, a lot of moves on the ground, and some near missed collisions that would cause loss of momentum. Also, the difficulty ramps up in a manageable manner, clearly a lot of testing stand behind it. Respawns are fast, putting you straight back into the action. 
I like the B and C sides being stand-alone, different levels, separated from the main story, as it allows players to choose how much difficulty they cam handle. In a similar vein, strawberries may not be pursued, but they always exist highlighting their good level design. Golden berries also for the insane people among us.

STORY:
The story is arguably not the main focus of the game, however it is charming and touching, exploring the mind field of Madeline's anxiety driven mind as well as witnessing her fostering relationships with the other characters. The main metaphore, her personified self doubt works nicely with the feeling of freedom given by her coming to terms with it, awarding the double dash.

MUSIC
The music is beautiful. For me it made the whole ordeal of trying over and over feel calmer, more relaxing.

MISC
PICO-8 is cute ngl.
The assist mode exists for players wanting to experience the game without frustration, but it, in my opinion, make the player feel like cheating, like they took the easy way out. Perhaps a better name would make it appear less handholding.

146815927.review:
One of the best platformers ever made, if not the best. A game that gives you access to only 3 simple movements (climb, jump, dash), yet it reaches an unbelievable high complexity and skill ceiling. Movement is as tight at it gets, and it is super satisfaying to play and control, especially after you get better in the game.
The main game is 7 chapters long and fairly tough the first time that you play it. After you finish it you get harder variations of the 7 chapters, plus the best chapter in this game "farewell". In general this game is like a reverse metroidvania. While in metroidvania the player gets more and more powers that allows it to enter more rooms in the map, in celeste the player has only 3 moves, yet YOU are getting better and better allowing you to utilize the moves in such a way that you can reach inaccessible (ie very hard) levels.

Maddy makes games, no son unos desconocidos para mi. Gracias a TOWERFALL ASCENSION, un multijugador de estos que te hacen perder los amigos, ya me habia enseñado su saber hacer en juegos de plataformas / accion lateral. Pero este CELESTE es algo mucho mas grande, de estos juegos que estan pensados de principio a fin, sin aristas. Una maravilla.

Sin saber muy bien porque, estas a la ladera de una montaña, encarnando a una adolescente, que ha decido darle sentido a su vida culminando la cima de este enorme predusco. Por el camino, sin entrar en spoiler, conoceremos a un variado repertorio de personajes que nos haran enfrentarnos a nuestros miedos y dudas. Aunque el guion por momento puede hacer sonrojar, tiene un trasfondo original y que pocas veces encontraremos en un video juego.

El punto fuerte, sin lugar a dudas, es su matematica jugabilidad. Partiendo de la base aportada por SUPER MEAT BOY hace decenios, este CELESTE mezcla la formula con puzzles, mapas de roguelite y miles de secretos. Los controles, sufren de una inercia similar al SMB, pero los lleva a un punto mas alla con un dash y muchisima variedad de situaciones. Tienes que jugarlo, cada nivel es una sorpresa. Ademas, te da hasta donde le pidas, cuanto mas dificultad le pides, es capaz de dartela, pero de manera medida. Solo tiene un pero, y es que las mecanicas de muelles (nubes, plataformas que explotan) se notan menos pulidas que el resto, y cuesta demasiado acostumbrarse a ellas.

A nivel tecnico, tiene un colorido soberbio, con una paleta de colores amplisima, que se ve reflejada en la extensa variedad de escenarios. Y por sino tuvieras bastante, la comunidad en NEXUS MODS, ha creado biomas aparte de los que vienen en el propio juego. Echale un vistazo en youtube a los mods y a los speedrun.

Lo tienes que probar, porque es un agujero de gusano, al que le puedes dedicar horas, pero lo principal, es que como "juego" es una maravilla. De principio a final.

146515285.review:
CELESTE

This is probably one of the best platformer games I have ever played. 
The idea of the game is really simple... You just have to climb a mountain... and you only have two skills, grabbing and dashing, although it is quite simple, its fairly hard to master once you realice that you have many "micro-mechanics", like wave dashing for instance.
However the story is nothing special, there is a deep meaning behind it, having emphasis in depression and anxiety, because Madeline is in a constant challenge with herself.

What is more, the pixel art of the game is just beautiful, every level has their own style and the music is unic and charming.
Finally and talking about the difficulty, as i mention before, is easy to learn but hard to master, thankfully the levels accompany you with the difficulty while you are learning the mechanics, but you are going to die many times anyways, the game is challenging you every second, even when you think that you know how to play the game, there is always something new to learn.

This game teaches you the importance of learning from your mistakes, and don't give up when things get tough.

10/10

146472143.review:
An infuriating, but satisfying uphill battle. Normally I would give up on a game that I have died 17,000+ times in, but it was totally worth pushing through. It's a beautiful game, with some great messages about mental health, growth, and learning to deal with challenges that makes all your failures and perseverance even more satisfying (something they tell you at the very beginning of the game). 
I played it normally and by the time i hit level 3, i knew this game was not messing around with the difficulty. There were many times I had to walk away. Many times I messaged a friend who also played asking what sort of masochistic psychopath decided anything this hard needed to exist. But when you finally get through every challenge this game throws at you, that "i can do hard things" feeling is overwhelmingly satisfying. You really feel so proud of yourself and the story only adds to that satisfaction.  
This game is for anyone. It's great for those looking for a new challenge. If you're not, there is an assist option to just experience the story if you don't care about that. 
100% Recommend.

So here's my humble opinion on Anxiety: the game.
Celeste is the 3rd best thing that came outta Canada... right behind Jim Carrey and Celine Dion. It's one of those games that prove video games should be considered as art. 
Basically, Celeste is a tiny little game that teaches you to be patient with yourself and learn from your mistakes. You're gonna die a lot figuring your way up a mountain. Hopefully with each death you learn what do to do and how to do it, so you can reach the summit. That's basically the game; You climb despite numerous obstacles that are on your way. The starting mechanics are as simple as it gets: You can jump, hold onto walls and dash. The game successfully tries to keep things fresh with adding new mechanics and different type of obstacles in each section of the game. There'll be many challenging parts in the game but if you give yourself enough time to think and rest, it'll never become frustrating and believe me, you'll feel great after overcoming challenges that at first appeared to be impossible to get through.
Despite the story being a simple one, it's really impactful and memorable. Just like how the gameplay teaches you, it have messages about self reflection, self acceptance and self love. I really really liked the story, characters and the little cute interactions here and there.
If you haven't grabbed this game already, I totally recommend you to do asap. It's a great one.

146258222.review:
It took me quite a while to fully appreciate Celeste. My very first playthrough I believe was in 2020 on the Nintendo Switch, and I remember beating the base game, liking it, and shoving it into the back of my brain. I HEAVILY regret this because Celeste, while incredibly difficult at times, is one of the best games I have EVER PLAYED, and I play a lot of games. 

In this second PC playthrough, I decided to take my time, as I planned to get every achievement in the game without using assist mode ONCE. I'll say, I was seriously tempted to use it, especially at parts like b-side chapter 7, c-side chapter 8, and who could forget the classic Chapter 9. No joke, Farewell is one of the HARDEST challenges I have EVER faced in a video game. It's up there with the Pantheon of Hallownest from Hollow Knight and the Malenia boss fight from Elden Ring in terms of difficulty. What made it more difficult is that I tried to get the Moonberry BEFORE I beat Farewell normally, which made beating it EVEN MORE OF A PAIN.

Nevertheless, after 12,000 total deaths, 44 total hours, and multiple rage quits, I got every achievement in Celeste, fairly. Even with that being said, I doubt I am truly done with this amazing game. I still have Variant mode to play around with, attempts at speedruns, and if I'm feeling truly masochistic, the Golden strawberries. Even if you aren't interested in 100%ing games, it's still a great 2D platformer with an amazingly written story. So do me a favor, and show it some love.

146163011.review: Perfect Game #59, Celeste.  Celeste is a hard game and it knows it.  Right from the start it offers a challenge, but it gives you the tools to overcome those challenges.  The dash in Celeste is probably my favorite movement option in any game.  The wide variety of movement options that it provides makes for such a fast and fun ride.  You can fly across large gaps, you can launch yourself off of a ledge to another that seemed just out of reach moments ago, you are capable of incredible things.  That's what Celeste is all about; it's about you overcoming your own doubts and climbing your own mountain.  Some may find it easier than others, but comparing isn't the point.  Learning how to overcome things at your own pace and taking your time is what it's all about.  Of course there's a lot more than that along the way, mostly rage and sadness.  Celeste is about the journey, and through it's incredible story and characters you'll see Madeline's journey.  Celeste won't be for everyone, but it is absolutely worth it if you want to challenge yourself to climb the mountain, both mentally and physically.

145877076.review:
Now that I've reached 69 hours, it's time to write a review.

Celeste is one of the best games of all time. You come for its unique atmosphere (established by the cute pixel art graphics, unforgettable characters, and amazing music), you stay for the platforming challenge.

Celeste has a learning curve like no other game. The first time you play the first chapter, you die hundreds of times. A month later, you can do it completely deathless. The first time you attempt a B-side stage, you think it's impossible, designed for superhumans and robots. A month later, you've beaten all of them. I once thought the Summit was impossibly hard. Then I thought Summit B-side was impossibly hard. Nowadays, I think C-side is impossibly hard and so is Farewell. Maybe soon I'll look back at this review and chuckle.

Getting better at the game involves a lot of dying, but it rarely feels unfair. You always get taught everything you need ahead of time. It's a matter of perfecting your inputs. If you want to accelerate the process, I recommend increasing your estrogen dose. Also, a bad controller can really hold you back, since you may need to switch between horizontal, vertical, and diagonal inputs frequently in the fraction of a second.

Every time you beat a stage you once thought was impossible, you'll feel a joy that few other things can provide,
You all should play this game if you want to experience personal growth, as a gamer or just as a human.

Addendum: If you're out of things to do in the base game, I recommend giving the Strawberry Jam mod a try.
